comments.commentBody: Tomato rot made me a teat...I mean it ATE AT me A certain five minute error in a nice challenge as it were no beer and skittles puzzle, heh. .

South American trivia: Don Puma is the Chilean equivalent of Smokey the Bear. Milanese trivia: Ambrose is the patron saint of the city. Brazilian trivia: the southern-most state in the country is RIo Grande do Sul. Wags trivia: he had never heard of hyson.

Great puzzle, thanks Ned.
Al Kaline.

The breadwinner should NEVER be the one to quit their job. Period.

Does the dad want to stay home?

I'm a stay at home mom, but my husband outearned by 3 or 4 to 1 and my salary would barely cover a nanny. It just made sense for me to be at home. But if would never be ok for him, as the person whose salary pays the bills to quit.

My husband and I really struggled with this, making long lists of pros and cons, and debating back and forth about whether or not to have kids. I understood and agreed with all of his logical reasons not to have kids. But I finally realized that this wasn't going to be a logical decision for me. We have an 11-month-old baby now, and both of us are thrilled with our decision!
Breesus is the reason for the season!

It's certainly the case that not a lot of "Insiders" are picking the Jets. But most of Rivers' success comes from 7 step drop passes , and those take alot of time to unfold. If the deep threat is effectively removed with fast tempo and timing, that makes the Chargers less three dimensional, more predictable, and more vulnerable to 3-and-outs. If those happen early and often, then the time of posession stat will be in the Jets' favor.

And then there's the concept of depriving a potent QB of ever establishing a rhythm. Why can't Rivers be rattled and shaken off his game, just like Palmer was? I think that will be the Jets' game plan.

Walt's first observation that "We have to make the Chargers play bad. We are not near good enough to outplay them if they play well" is exactly right, and is the key to victory for the Jets.

Go Gang Green!

I LOVE John's blog and actually included it in an item I recently wrote about the best designer blogs(Loeffler Randall, Vena Cava and Anna Sheffield of Bing Bang also have great blogs). Anyone who's interested can check it out here: http://thefashioninformer.typepad.com...

Can't imagine there are no people reviews of this 1998 film that I have just viewed.  On one level, the simple act of dancing is magical. On another level, there is an undercurrent of former bad times & no one wanting to talk about it -- not good. I wonder and don't know if this film got any recognition, but it surely should have.

My son was very collicky for the first few months.  I remember being in tears because I couldn't sooth him until, in depersation, I took a warm bath with him whihc seemed to do the trick most times. I would cradle him between my knees so his was submerged but safe.  He's 12, now, and still takes a bath to soothe himself.
Wait.  New Mexico is "standing in for America" ??   And here I thought that pesky statehood issue had been resolved.
And still the voters keep him in office.  Term limits is the only way to help keep our politicians from becoming power hunger rulers.  Will Bloomberg become the forever "King" of New York?

This article misses the whole point of the bonuses. These executives came with him from Bloomberg; they can earn prodigious amounts of money working for a private company. He's using the campaign to compensate them enough to keep them on board without using the city's funds.

It's a fair trade: the Bloomberg administration is staffed with hyper-competent executives and it doesn't cost NYC an extra dime.

Kudos to the NY Times, which offers a lucid preview of Jets/Chargers. I've been amazed this week at the sheer number of columnists who lean to the Jets, even though the smart money has San Diego as a touchdown favorite. I'm sure it's a coincidence that 95 percent of said writers are New York based.

This year Brad Childress, Wade Phillips, and Norv Turner are all going to get coach of the year votes. Nice to see three guys who still don't understand the challenge rules, how to use time outs, or might not even understand the game of football itself are going to be rewarded for their ineptitude. At least Rex Ryan built a defense, even if he is completely insane.

I'd vote Ray Rice since he is really good. Of course it helps if you touch him when you try to stop him. I hate the Patriots.
All I can say is that it is a very interesting business idea.  If some of those stuff that they sell in late night infomercials can sell, why not this idea?
Next, there will be a terrorist reality show. America is sick.
Now that's a drive-by!

Strasbourg + Chez Yvonne + choucroute = Heaven

Strasbourg is an amazing city. I would move there in a nanosecond if I could.
Color is not an issue, as most (90%) of combat (Infantry) spraypaint their system per where they are at in country.

We stayed in Florence at Tuscany hotel and we booked form http://www.servifans.com at very cheap price.

Hotel it's placed near to Florence airport and 30 minutes walking from cultural places but hotel offers "free" transfer by bus to Piazza Republica.

for shopping fanatics we recommended visit all outlets from italian fashion companies as Versave , Prada , etc....

If you stay in Tuscany hotel or book throught http://www.servifans.com they will send you a list of most important outlets with adresses.

Enjoy Florence.
great puzzle
55 Dow, Ito is not a contemporary of Baiul.  Midori Ito had retired after the '92 Olympics.  Oksana Baiul debuted in '93.  Nice try though

Since you mentioned Ned White, the name that came to my mind was Jack Black.

Anybody remember Bob Thingama?

Steve I: My impression was that Mr. Merrell was looking for last-name-first examples, but I thought Al Kaline was a great and funny find.

My second straight trouble-free run through of a Saturday puzzle, this one in about 20 minutes. I'm feeling quite full of myself these days; Lord knows what comedown awaits--probably on a Thursday or Friday like two weeks ago.

I always assumed that ASPIC was some kind of gelatinized meat juice; hard to imagine how it relates to what we think of as mold.

To me, this fine puzzle had more than the usual number of occasions for relating words I was familiar with, but whose meanings or origins I had never quite wrestled to the ground, with clues that left me befuddled. Helpful crosswords gave me the inklings I needed to toss these denizens of the ragged edges of my mind into the stew. These included the aforementioned 9A, plus 11D, 13D, and 36A. On the other hand, 14A, 51A, 61A, 62A, 49D, and 57D were new to me.

I'm curious about 22A: Doesn't that particular suffix at least potentially refer to one of the taboo areas for NYT crosswords?
